{
  "paper_metadata": {
    "title": "Can a community-managed conditional cash transfer program reduce poverty in Sub-Saharan Africa?",
    "matches_expected_title": "NO"
  },
  "program_information": {
    "program_name": "Tanzania Social Action Fund (TASAF) Conditional Cash Transfer (CCT) Program",
    "country": "Tanzania",
    "region": "Bagamoyo, Chamwino, and Kibaha districts",
    "target_population": "Vulnerable households, including young children (ages 0-5) and the elderly (ages 60 and over)"
  },
  "intervention_components": {
    "component_a_cash_support": {
      "component_a_present": true,
      "cash_support_type": "conditional cash transfer (CCT)",
      "cash_amount": "US $14.50 per month",
      "cash_frequency": "every other month (six times per year)",
      "is_loan_or_credit": "NO",
      "cash_evidence_citation": "Payments were made every other month, or six times each year, and averaged about US $14.50 per month (about 13 percent of total expenditures)."
    },
    "component_b_assets": {
      "component_b_present": false,
      "assets_provided": [],
      "direct_provision": "NO",
      "assets_evidence_citation": "No mention of asset transfers or provision found in the paper."
    }
  },

    "outcomes_measured": [
      "health outcomes",
      "education outcomes",
      "poverty reduction",
      "livestock ownership",
      "savings",
      "credit",
      "expenditure on insurance",
      "participation in health insurance programs",
      "anthropometrics (e.g., height, weight, BMI)"
    ],
    "outcomes_evidence_citation": "We examine the program impacts on all of these outcomes: health clinic visits, health during the last month, livestock ownership, savings, credit, expenditure on insurance, participation in the CHF, anthropometrics (height, weight, middle upper-arm circumference, and z-scores for height-for-age, weight-for-age, weight-for-height, and body mass index-for-age).",
    "study_design": "Randomized Controlled Trial (RCT)",
    "design_evidence_citation": "The pilot CCT program was implemented in three districts-Bagamoyo, Chamwino, and Kibaha-where 80 eligible study villages were randomized into treatment and control groups of 40 villages each, stratified on village size and district.",
    "is_review_or_policy_analysis": false,
    "publication_year": null,
    "study_conducted_year": "2010-2012",
    "sample_size": 1764,
    "completed": true
  },
  "bonus_information": {
    "has_qualitative_components": true,
    "qualitative_methods": ["focus group discussions", "in-depth interviews"],
    "qualitative_evidence_citation": "The quantitative data collection was supplemented by two rounds of qualitative data collection (following midline and endline) employing focus group discussions and in-depth interviews.",
    "has_cost_data": false,
    "cost_mentions": null,
    "cost_evidence_citation": "No mention of cost data or cost-effectiveness found in the paper."
  },
  "evidence_citations": {
    "program_name_citation": "The pilot CCT program was implemented by the TASAF which was keenly interested in understanding the program's impacts and how its design might be improved for an eventual scale-up of the program.",
    "country_citation": "The pilot CCT program was implemented by the TASAF which was keenly interested in understanding the program's impacts and how its design might be improved for an eventual scale-up of the program.",
    "target_population_citation": "The principal goals of the CCT were to increase investments in health for young children (ages 0-5) and the elderly (ages 60 and over) and to increase educational investments for children aged 7-15."
